• HR paperwork, IT setup, security training. | Establish trust and compliance. | Use a pre‑filled onboarding packet; schedule a quick “welcome” video call with the team. | | **Day 1 – Role Clarification** | • Meet with the hiring manager to review the project brief, deliverables, and success metrics. | Clear expectations from the start. | Ask for a written scope of work and a timeline; confirm who the key stakeholders are. | | **Day 2 – Tools & Processes** | • Access to project management, communication, and documentation tools.
• Overview of internal workflows (e.g., sprint planning, reporting cadence). | Reduce friction in daily tasks. | Provide a quick‑start guide and a “cheat sheet” for the most used features. | | **Day 3 – Team Integration** | • One‑on‑one meetings with teammates and stakeholders.
• Shadow a current consultant on a live task. | Build relationships and learn the context. | Keep meetings short (15‑20 min) and focused on “What do you need from me?” | | **Day 4 – Knowledge Transfer** | • Review of past project artifacts, lessons learned, and key contacts. | Avoid reinventing the wheel. | Create a shared “knowledge hub” (e.g., Confluence page) with links to templates and playbooks. | | **Day 5 – First Deliverable** | • Draft a small, low‑risk deliverable (e.g., a stakeholder interview guide or a quick audit).
• Receive feedback from the manager. | Test the process and get early validation. | Set a realistic deadline (≤ 2 days) and use a simple review form. | | **End of Week – Reflection & Planning** | • One‑on‑one with manager to discuss what worked, what didn’t, and next steps. | Continuous improvement. | Ask for a 30‑minute “retrospective” and set a personal KPI for the next week. | **General Best Practices** 1. **Prepare in Advance** – Send a welcome packet and a “first‑day agenda” a week before arrival. 2. **Assign a Buddy** – Pair the new consultant with an experienced teammate for informal guidance. 3. **Keep Communication Transparent** – Use a shared channel (e.g., Slack #new‑consultant) for quick questions. 4. **Document Everything** – Capture decisions, action items, and learnings in a shared doc. 5. **Set Early Wins** – Identify a small, high‑impact task that can be completed within the first week. • HR paperwork, IT setup, security training. | Establish trust and compliance. | Use a pre‑filled onboarding packet; schedule a quick “welcome” video call with the team. | | **Day 1 – Role Clarification** | • Meet with the hiring manager to review the project brief, deliverables, and success metrics. | Clear expectations from the start. | Ask for a written scope of work and a timeline; confirm who the key stakeholders are. | | **Day 2 – Tools & Processes** | • Access to project management, communication, and documentation tools.
• Overview of internal workflows (e.g., sprint planning, reporting cadence). | Reduce friction in daily tasks. | Provide a quick‑start guide and a “cheat sheet” for the most used features. | | **Day 3 – Team Integration** | • One‑on‑one meetings with teammates and stakeholders.
• Shadow a current consultant on a live task. | Build relationships and learn the context. | Keep meetings short (15‑20 min) and focused on “What do you need from me?” | | **Day 4 – Knowledge Transfer** | • Review of past project artifacts, lessons learned, and key contacts. | Avoid reinventing the wheel. | Create a shared “knowledge hub” (e.g., Confluence page) with links to templates and playbooks. | | **Day 5 – First Deliverable** | • Draft a small, low‑risk deliverable (e.g., a stakeholder interview guide or a quick audit).
• Receive feedback from the manager. | Test the process and get early validation. | Set a realistic deadline (≤ 2 days) and use a simple review form. | | **End of Week – Reflection & Planning** | • One‑on‑one with manager to discuss what worked, what didn’t, and next steps. | Continuous improvement. | Ask for a 30‑minute “retrospective” and set a personal KPI for the next week. | **General Best Practices** 1. **Prepare in Advance** – Send a welcome packet and a “first‑day agenda” a week before arrival. 2. **Assign a Buddy** – Pair the new consultant with an experienced teammate for informal guidance. 3. **Keep Communication Transparent** – Use a shared channel (e.g., Slack #new‑consultant) for quick questions. 4. **Document Everything** – Capture decisions, action items, and learnings in a shared doc. 5. **Set Early Wins** – Identify a small, high‑impact task that can be completed within the first week. By following this structured yet flexible approach, you’ll help new consultants hit the ground running, build confidence, and align quickly with the team’s goals.
